message.content: We refer to CDC guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis for help. Based on the patient's history of incomplete tetanus vaccination, the presence of a contaminated wound, and symptoms of tetanus, the next best step in management would be administration of tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) along with tetanus-diphtheria vaccine (Td). Tdap would be recommended in a patient who has not received a pertussis-containing vaccine, but this is not the case here. DTaP is not recommended for use in adults.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of childhood tetanus series and last booster more than 10 years ago indicates the need for tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) to provide immediate passive immunity against tetanus toxin. Tdap and DTaP are not needed as he has already completed his primary tetanus series. Td is not necessary as TIG is recommended for wound prophylaxis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of a contaminated wound, and his last tetanus booster was more than 10 years ago, so he should receive a tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) along with a Tetanus-diphtheria (Td) booster. Tdap is not indicated in this scenario as it contains an additional pertussis component that is not necessary. DTaP is a pediatric vaccine and is not indicated for this adult patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a wound and is at risk for tetanus, and his last booster was more than 10 years ago. Therefore, the next best step is to administer tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG). Tdap and DTaP are vaccines that can help prevent tetanus, but they are not appropriate for immediate treatment of a wound. Td is a booster vaccine and also not appropriate for immediate treatment of a wound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s last tetanus booster was over 10 years ago and he has a contaminated wound with jaw discomfort and limited mouth opening, indicating tetanus infection. The next best step in management is Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG). Tdap is not necessary since the patient has already received the primary tetanus series. Td and DTaP only protect against tetanus and diphtheria, not the actual infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of a cut and is displaying symptoms consistent with tetanus. Treatment should include giving tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG). Tdap and DTaP are vaccines and do not provide immediate protection. Td is a booster shot for tetanus but it should be given alongside TIG in cases of suspected or confirmed tetanus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a wound and is at risk for tetanus infection. Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) should be administered to patients who have not received a primary series or have incomplete tetanus vaccination history and have a wound that is likely to be contaminated. Tdap or Td should also be administered for tetanus toxoid boosters, but TIG is necessary in this case. DTaP is not appropriate for adult patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a wound that could potentially lead to tetanus infection, and his last booster was more than 10 years ago. Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) should be given to neutralize the toxin already produced by Clostridium tetani in the wound, followed by a tetanus toxoid booster. Tdap is not appropriate in this situation, as the patient has already received his childhood tetanus series. DTaP is for children and is not appropriate for adults. Td is appropriate for adults but does not contain tetanus immunoglobulin, which is necessary in cases of wound contamination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a tetanus-prone wound and has not had a booster in over 10 years, so Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) should be given along with Td or Tdap. The wound care and antibiotic treatment are also appropriate steps in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a contaminated wound and it has been more than 5 years since his last booster. Tetanus immunoglobulin is indicated for wound care and tetanus prevention in patients with contaminated wounds who have not had a dose of tetanus toxoid within the past 5 years. Tdap or Td are indicated as tetanus boosters, but TIG is recommended for those with contaminated wounds who are at risk for tetanus but have not had a booster within the past 5 years. DTaP is not indicated for adults.
